page.title: 03The Landscape of Bramdean
page.content: Bramdean is situated in a shallow dry valley in chalk downland. It has one of the largest areas of beechwood in Hampshire. Another feature of the landscape are the small fields and ancient hedgerows with their numerous flowering trees. This pattern is interspersed with the scattered houses and farmsteads, which are mainly built of flint and brick with some old stone buildings. The majority of the houses in the area lie in the heart of the village; which is at the base of the valley, in the intersection of the main road with a lane leading to Bramdean Common. On the fringes of the village there are extensive views across the South Downs.
